articles.headline: Raisins Give Hope to Afghan Farmers
articles.snippet: An alliance among farmers, an aid group and a producer is helping to bring Afghan raisins to a wider market.
articles.abstract: An alliance among farmers, an aid group and a producer is helping to bring Afghan raisins to a wider market.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL — Raisin Producer Cooperative Center No. 2 stands alone astride the highway in Parwan Province, an hour north of Kabul. Inside the clay-colored building with a cheery yellow gate, a group of Afghan raisin farmers sits cross-legged on the tan carpet, talking about the past — and the future.

articles.headline: Flying Fewer Planes, Airlines Find Stability
articles.snippet: The scaling back in flights reflects a more timid — and perhaps chastened — industry than in previous decades.
articles.abstract: The scaling back in flights reflects a more timid — and perhaps chastened — industry than in previous decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: VICTORVILLE, Calif.  For the first time since their industry was deregulated in the late 1970s, airlines in the United States have managed to hold the line on the number of planes they fly.

articles.headline: Apple Plans to Offer iPhone on Verizon
articles.snippet: After more than three years of using AT&T networks, Apple is said to be making an iPhone 4 for Verizon.
articles.abstract: After more than three years of using AT&T networks, Apple is said to be making an iPhone 4 for Verizon.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Facing intense competition from phone makers wedded to Google’s Android software, Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, finally plans to make the iPhone available on Verizon Wireless, the largest wireless carrier in the United States.

articles.headline: A Double Standard at H.P.
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard’s board, which ousted its former chief executives for ethical lapses, may have ignored an ethical issue involving its new chief executive.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard’s board, which ousted its former chief executives for ethical lapses, may have ignored an ethical issue involving its new chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: And so it came to pass that on the 55th day — 55 days, that is, after firing its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, for playing footsie with a consultant and fudging his expense accounts — the board of directors at Hewlett-Packard proudly announced it had found a new man to lead the company out of the wilderness.

articles.headline: After Foreclosure, a Focus on Title Insurance
articles.snippet: Title insurance might feel like a tax during the home-buying process, but the questions now surrounding foreclosures have made its importance crystal-clear.
articles.abstract: Title insurance might feel like a tax during the home-buying process, but the questions now surrounding foreclosures have made its importance crystal-clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: When home buyers and people refinancing their mortgages first see the itemized estimate for all the closing costs and fees, the largest number is often for title insurance.

articles.headline: Campaign Gaffes Highlight 2 Jerry Browns
articles.snippet: An aide’s crude remark about Jerry Brown’s opponent in the California governor’s race reminded many of a dichotomy in Mr. Brown’s long career.
articles.abstract: An aide’s crude remark about Jerry Brown’s opponent in the California governor’s race reminded many of a dichotomy in Mr. Brown’s long career.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  On Wednesday night, at a party held for young San Francisco Democrats, Jerry Brown took the microphone and gave the kind of stirring, if somewhat eccentric, speech that has defined his 40 years in politics.

articles.headline: Activism of Thomas’s Wife Could Raise Judicial Issues
articles.snippet: Virginia Thomas, wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, has accepted large contributions for her new political nonprofit group, raising questions for some who study judicial ethics.
articles.abstract: Virginia Thomas, wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, has accepted large contributions for her new political nonprofit group, raising questions for some who study judicial ethics.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va.  As one of the keynote speakers here Friday at a state convention billed as the largest Tea Party event ever, Virginia Thomas gave the throng of more than 2,000 activists a full-throated call to arms for conservative principles.

articles.headline: A Shoemaker That Walks but Never Runs
articles.snippet: Tod’s, the luxury Italian shoemaker, has become a multibillion-dollar multinational, but its operations still ooze with Old World tradition.
articles.abstract: Tod’s, the luxury Italian shoemaker, has become a multibillion-dollar multinational, but its operations still ooze with Old World tradition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sant’Elpidio a Mare, Italy

articles.headline: Drill Reaches Miners in Chile, but Risks Remain
articles.snippet: A rescue attempt remains days away as officials plan to reinforce the shaft before they try to hoist out the 33 miners who have been trapped since August.
articles.abstract: A rescue attempt remains days away as officials plan to reinforce the shaft before they try to hoist out the 33 miners who have been trapped since August.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ MINE, Chile — It was a moment of euphoria.
articles.byline: By Alexei Barrionuevo and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Vilified or Not, Pelosi Insists She’s Winning
articles.snippet: On the brink of an election that could end Nancy Pelosi’s run as speaker of the House, her recent doings underscore an enduring truth: This most vilified of politicians is also one of the most resolute.
articles.abstract: On the brink of an election that could end Nancy Pelosi’s run as speaker of the House, her recent doings underscore an enduring truth: This most vilified of politicians is also one of the most resolute.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  While polls were showing her to be among the country’s most disliked politicians, Democrats were ducking her on the campaign trail and the Republican Party chairman was riding around in a “Fire Pelosi!” bus, the speaker of the House was checking out mattresses.

articles.headline: Whistle. Then Worry and Wait.
articles.snippet: In order to help the F.B.I., Ty Schlobohm had to watch the swindling of investors as a Ponzi scheme progressed.
articles.abstract: In order to help the F.B.I., Ty Schlobohm had to watch the swindling of investors as a Ponzi scheme progressed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SITTING in a Minneapolis mansion and listening to a charismatic investment manager describe a currency trading system that kept earning handsome returns year after year, Arthur F. Schlobohm IV was certain he had stumbled onto a Ponzi scheme.

articles.headline: It’s Not Nice to Mess With J.R.
articles.snippet: Larry Hagman, who played J. R. Ewing on “Dallas,” said he was surprised by the arbitration award he won in a dispute with Citigroup, but thought it was justified.
articles.abstract: Larry Hagman, who played J. R. Ewing on “Dallas,” said he was surprised by the arbitration award he won in a dispute with Citigroup, but thought it was justified.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN he played the oil tycoon J. R. Ewing Jr., in “Dallas,” the long-running, ’80s-era nighttime soap opera, Larry Hagman didn’t get mad at his adversaries. He got even.

articles.headline: Specialists’ Help at Court Can Come With a Catch
articles.snippet: An increasingly influential number of lawyers specialize in Supreme Court cases, many serving free to draw prestige and paying clients to their firms.
articles.abstract: An increasingly influential number of lawyers specialize in Supreme Court cases, many serving free to draw prestige and paying clients to their firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Humberto Fernandez-Vargas, deported to Mexico, had run out of options. A federal appeals court said he could not return to the United States to live with his American wife and son. And his lawyer did not have the expertise or money to pursue the case further.

articles.headline: China Emerges as a Scapegoat in Campaign Ads
articles.snippet: With many Americans anxious over economic decline, Democrats and Republicans are blaming one another for allowing the export of jobs.
articles.abstract: With many Americans anxious over economic decline, Democrats and Republicans are blaming one another for allowing the export of jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: With many Americans seized by anxiety about the country’s economic decline, candidates from both political parties have suddenly found a new villain to run against: China.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Poised to Make Gains in Races for Governor
articles.snippet: A wave of G.O.P. victories could have a profound effect on several issues, including health care, Congressional redistricting and stimulus packages.
articles.abstract: A wave of G.O.P. victories could have a profound effect on several issues, including health care, Congressional redistricting and stimulus packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republicans are well-positioned to pick up a substantial number of governor’s seats in this year’s election, with potentially far-reaching effects on issues like the new health care law, Congressional redistricting and presidential politics.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Bloomberg Plans a Data Service on the Business of Government
articles.snippet: Bloomberg L.P. wants to create a resource that provides information on the nuts-and-bolts of lawmaking and government regulation.
articles.abstract: Bloomberg L.P. wants to create a resource that provides information on the nuts-and-bolts of lawmaking and government regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ambition and confidence have never been in short supply at Bloomberg L.P.

articles.headline: A Vanishing Journalistic Divide
articles.snippet: More and more, the dichotomy between mainstream media and digital media is a false one.
articles.abstract: More and more, the dichotomy between mainstream media and digital media is a false one.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you were going to pick an epicenter for mainstream media, The Washington Post’s Howard Kurtz would not be a bad place to land. With his running scorecard on Beltway journalists, his interviews of other scorekeepers on his “Reliable Sources” show on CNN, and his ceaseless fascination with network news, Mr. Kurtz embodied the folkways of the traditional press.

articles.headline: After Building an Audience, Twitter Turns to Ads
articles.snippet: Google and Facebook are must-buys for advertisers online, and the ad industry is watching Twitter closely to see if it follows a similar path.
articles.abstract: Google and Facebook are must-buys for advertisers online, and the ad industry is watching Twitter closely to see if it follows a similar path.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter at last looks serious about making money.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: New Web Code Draws Concern Over Privacy Risks
articles.snippet: The new language, HTML5, could give marketers access to many more details about users’ online activities.
articles.abstract: The new language, HTML5, could give marketers access to many more details about users’ online activities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worries over Internet privacy have spurred lawsuits, conspiracy theories and consumer anxiety as marketers and others invent new ways to track computer users on the Internet. But the alarmists have not seen anything yet.

articles.headline: CBS Is a Network on a Roll
articles.snippet: Not only has CBS avoided any duds in its new slate, it is almost always first or second in all 22 hours that make up prime-time’s week.
articles.abstract: Not only has CBS avoided any duds in its new slate, it is almost always first or second in all 22 hours that make up prime-time’s week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three weeks into a new television season, the usual carnage is becoming apparent, with new shows collapsing and crises appearing all over network prime-time schedules.

articles.headline: Sluggish Economy Curtails Prospects for Building Nuclear Reactors
articles.snippet: The economic prognosis for new nuclear reactors has been hurt by the falling price of competing energy sources and a lack of climate legislation.
articles.abstract: The economic prognosis for new nuclear reactors has been hurt by the falling price of competing energy sources and a lack of climate legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Just a few years ago, the economic prognosis for new nuclear reactors looked bright. The prospect of growing electricity demand, probable caps on carbon-dioxide emissions and government loan guarantees prompted companies to tell the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that they wanted to build 28 new reactors.

articles.headline: Currency Rift With China Exposes Shifting Clout
articles.snippet: The financial crisis has shifted influence from the richest powers toward Asia and Latin America, whose economies have weathered the recession well.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis has shifted influence from the richest powers toward Asia and Latin America, whose economies have weathered the recession well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At a private dinner on Friday at the Canadian Embassy, finance officials from seven world economic powers focused on the most vexing international economic problem facing the Obama administration.

articles.headline: In Rough Slum, Brazil’s Police Try Soft Touch
articles.snippet: Officials have embarked on an ambitious plan to wrest control of Rio de Janeiro’s most violent slums from ruthless drug gangs.
articles.abstract: Officials have embarked on an ambitious plan to wrest control of Rio de Janeiro’s most violent slums from ruthless drug gangs.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO  Leonardo Bento longed for vengeance after a policeman killed his brother five years ago. So when he heard that the new “peace police” force in the City of God slum was offering free karate classes, Mr. Bento signed up, hoping he would at least get to beat up the karate instructor.

articles.headline: Economists Share Nobel for Studying Job Market
articles.snippet: Peter Diamond, Dale Mortensen and Christopher Pissarides won for work that helps explain mismatches in the employment market.
articles.abstract: Peter Diamond, Dale Mortensen and Christopher Pissarides won for work that helps explain mismatches in the employment market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Peter A. Diamond, a nominee for a Federal Reserve Board position, and two other economists were awarded the 2010 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science on Monday for their work on markets where buyers and sellers have difficulty finding each other.
